page.title: 03BRIGHTON GENERAL HOSPITAL
page.content: The Brighton General Hospital was first built as a workhouse.It covers 13 acres and cost Â£40,000 to build it. In 1865 it was owned by the parish of Brighton until 1948 when the government took it over with the National Health Service.During the 1st World War it was called the Kitchener Military Hospital & 2000 Indian soldiers were treated there.During the 2nd World War a large group of Belgian refugees consisting of children & nuns were brought over. Also Dunkirk wounded,air raid and general military patients were treated.Another incident of note was the dropping of a bomb on the tennis courts near 'B' block. Over the next 20 years considerable reconstruction was needed and it now has 546 beds including 159 chronic sick.
